comments.content:
You have two options for configuring Hybrid Linked Mode. You can use only one of these options at a time.

 You can install the Cloud Gateway Appliance and use it to link from your on-premises data center to your cloud SDDC. In this case, SSO users and groups are mapped from your on-premises environment to the SDDC and you do not need to add an identity source to the SDDC LDAP domain.
 You can link your cloud SDDC to your on-premises vCenter Server. In this case, you must add an identity source to the SDDC LDAP domain.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/brief-primer-vmware-transit-gateway-deployments#summary-and-considerations
Workload CIDRs should not overlap – if they do, remote overlapping networks are rejected.

Selected Answer: A
nemisis95 provided the correct link to the answer

Selected Answer: D
- Workload CIDRs should not overlap;if they do, remote overlapping networks are rejected.
- Note that the overlapping compute segments would not be advertised and are excluded from the vTGW route table
[https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/brief-primer-vmware-transit-gateway-deployments#sddc--sddc-connectivity]

If the overlapping ranges are excluded from the vTGW route table and are not advertised to vTGW by SDDC, it will ensure that both CIDR blocks work in both locations?

Selected Answer: A
A is Correct. Is clear in the documentation
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/introduction-vmware-transit-gateway-vmware-cloud-aws#prerequisites-and-best-practices

Selected Answer: B
https://blogs.vmware.com/networkvirtualization/2020/09/vmware-transit-connect-simplifying-networking-for-vmc.html/

 SDDCs must be at release 1.11 or higher
 SDDCs and VPCs that are members of a SDDC group MUST be in the same region
 SDDC management CIDRs MUST not overlap
 SDDC networks shouldn’t overlap but if they do, know that overlapping segments won’t be advertised

B
The requirements to use VMware Transit Connect are as follows: 
• SDDCs must be at release 1.11 or later. 
• SDDCs and VPCs that are members of a SDDC group must be in the same region. 
• SDDC management CIDRs must not overlap.
• SDDC networks should not overlap. If they do overlap, the overlapping segments are not advertised.
I agree with A
A is correct.

Selected Answer: A
https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/brief-primer-vmware-transit-gateway-deployments#summary-and-considerations

Workload CIDRs should not overlap – if they do, remote overlapping networks are rejected.

I think the answer should be A.

https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/brief-primer-vmware-transit-gateway-deployments#summary-and-considerations or https://vmc.techzone.vmware.com/resource/introduction-vmware-transit-gateway-vmware-cloud-aws#architecture

Workload CIDRs should not overlap – if they do, remote overlapping networks are rejected.

Selected Answer: B
VMware Transit Connect Requirements
The requirements to use VMware Transit Connect are as follows: • SDDCs must be at release 1.11 or later. • SDDCs and VPCs that are members of a SDDC group must be in the same region. • SDDC management CIDRs must not overlap.
• SDDC networks should not overlap. If they do overlap, the overlapping segments are not advertised.

questions.question_text: Upon connecting a VMware Managed Transit Gateway (VTGW), the administrator discovers that there is an overlapping workload CIDR bleck. How will the software-defined data center (SDDC) handle the overlapping IP space?

choices.B: AWS Elastic Network Adapter (ENA) on the VMware ESXI host

discussion.content: The VPC located in AWS passes packet to T0 Router, then T1, then the ENA

Selected Answer: B
The packet from the virtual machine must exit the ESXi host first.
So it would hit the ENA first.

C
NSX-T Data Center uses Tier 0 router to provide connectivity between VMware Cloud on AWS SDDC and other AWS services through ENIs.
Because NSX Edge appliances are attached only to the Tier 0 router, Tier 1 cannot offer any stateful services, such as load balancing.
I agree with D

I think the answer is D.
The next hop would not be the NIC in the host it would be the next networking device, in this case the T1 router (the CGW).

D. Tier-1 (T1) Router
IMO
